text: treet doesn’t usually include a letter from the editor in its annual Penn 10 issue. After all, the accomplishments of our featured stand–out seniors tend to speak for themselves.
But this year felt a little different.
The Class of 2021 has weathered what few of us could have predicted would come to pass when we were sent home that fateful March 2020 day: a fully online school year.

These Quakers spent their last lap around the track navigating Zoom meetings, time zone differences, and social distancing mandates. They lamented the loss of traditional milestones associated with flying the coop that now had the labels “virtual” or “limited in–person attendance” tacked onto them.
Yet, as the profiles that fill the pages of this year’s Penn 10 issue illustrate, even a pandemic couldn’t stop this year’s graduating class from leaving a legacy behind at dear old Penn.

From [spearheading student activism](https://www.34st.com/article/2021/05/penn-10-amanpreet-singh-activism-transgender-inclusion-justice-language-guide) to [working as contact tracers](https://www.34st.com/article/2021/05/penn-10-sydney-lewis-hillel-contact-tracing-vaccine-clinic-volunteer) to [running organic chemistry workshops](https://www.34st.com/article/2021/05/adam-konkol-student-profile-senior-penn-10-science-research-teaching), this year’s soon–to–be–graduates found unique ways to make their marks amid the chaos.
And that, dear readers, deserves a mention.
Tomorrow, we’ll go back to picking up the pieces of a life uprooted by COVID–19. But today, we celebrate our kickass Class of 2021.
editor_letter.subheading: Class of 2021, this one's for you.
editor_letter.author: Hannah Lonser

penn_declassified.subheading: Calling all incoming first-years: Street's Penn 10 answered your burning questions about all things campus culture, including how to make friends, handle the hookup scene, and budget your dining dollars.
penn_declassified.author: Jesse Zhang

profiles.subhead: There's no such thing as free time or work when you love what you do, even if it's being a student, teacher, and researcher all at once.

profiles.subhead: This Penn student bridges humanities and health care with a passion for translated poetry and violence prevention.

profiles.name: Amanpreet Singh
profiles.subhead: The former Street writer reflects on trans inclusion, University politics, and loving the cliches of the Penn experience.

profiles.subhead: This Halo co–founder is a social justice advocate, die–hard Philly sports fan, and chocolate milk enthusiast.

profiles.name: Julia Klayman
profiles.subhead: The tour guide extraordinaire and creative writing enthusiast loves learning, even from her own failures.

profiles.subhead: From consulting in Sri Lanka to potato farming in Norway, this Toronto native shares his passion for sustainability with the world.
